### Steps to reproduce

@tgamblin as discussed yesterday:

If you use `spack load` and `spack unload` with packages that set their environment by sourcing a file, e.g. basically all Intel packages, there will be residual environment variables after `unload`. 

This happens because `spack unload` actually runs `uenv.environment_modifications_for_spec`, i.e. the same as `spack load` and reverses the output. Let's say there is a package that sources a file with the following content:
```console
export PATH=$PATH:/a/new/path
export MY_ENV_VARIABLE=something
```

When calling `spack load` `uenv.environment_modifications_for_spec` will report `appendPath(PATH, /a/new/path); setPath(MY_ENV_VARIABLE, something)`.

When subsequently calling `spack unload` `uenv.environment_modifications_for_spec` will report `appendPath(PATH, /a/new/path)` as `MY_ENV_VARIABLE` seems not to have changed. So, the `reverse()` function cannot generate the correct unload commands.

This is on the develop branch.

Minimal example where this is an issue (because `I_MPI_ROOT` will be picked up by other MPI packages as well):
